overview: From 2025-10-01 to 2025-11-01, ethereum-optimism/docs had 25 new PRs (18 merged), 6 new issues, and 73 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Issue on docs: some internal links in tutorials are broken
topIssues.author: mablr
topIssues.body:
Hi,
While exploring the wonderful optimism doc website, I noticed that some internal links are broken. 

For instance at:
Path: /chain-operators/tutorials/create-l2-rollup/
Url: https://docs.optimism.io/chain-operators/tutorials/create-l2-rollup/create-l2-rollup#manual-tutorial-overview

The links in this section are pointing to `https://docs.optimism.io/operators/chain-operators/tutorials/create-l2-rollup/*`(leading 404 errors) while the tutorial pages stages are available at `https://docs.optimism.io/chain-operators/tutorials/create-l2-rollup/*`

I guess it's a redirection/migration problem that could solved here:
https://github.com/ethereum/optimism/docs/blob/16e50b51f8e7a8c040ad4dd6cffe6c0ca2576bbe/public/_redirects
I tried fix it by myself following the contribution guide, but I was unable to reproduce the problem on local dev env, maybe I missed smtg...

Thanks for your attention ðŸ˜Š

topIssues.title: [2024 Q4 Audit] [page-path]
topIssues.author: kelvin7891
topIssues.body:
<!-- this template is intended for internal OP Labs usage -->

## Description of the updates required

<!-- Write a description of the current state of the page. -->

### Acceptance criteria

<!-- Definition of done for the assignee -->

### Resources

<!-- Supporting docs, points of contact, and any additional helpful info -->

### Action items

<!-- The process for working through this issue for example:
1. Read through resources and meet with SME
2. Write the first draft
3. Share draft with SMEs and implement feedback
4. Peer review
5. Final SME review
6. Publish -->

## Github issue label criteria

> Choose the appropriate github issue labels for each page.

<details>

<summary>Priority</summary>

- `p-on-hold`: (Defer) Tasks that are currently not actionable due to various reasons like waiting for external inputs, dependencies, or resource constraints. These are reviewed periodically to decide if they can be moved to a more active status.
- `p-low`: (Nice to do) Tasks that have minimal impact on core operations and no immediate deadlines. These tasks are often more about quality of life improvements rather than essential needs.
- `p-medium`: (Could do) Tasks that need to be done but are less critical than high-priority tasks. These often improve processes or efficiency but can be postponed if necessary without immediate severe repercussions.
- `p-high`: (Should do) Important tasks that contribute significantly to long-term goals but may not have an immediate deadline. Delaying these tasks could have considerable negative effects but are not as immediate as critical tasks.
- `p-critical`: Tasks that have immediate deadlines or significant consequences if not completed on time. These are non-negotiable and often linked to core business functions or legal requirements. 
</details>

<details>

<summary>T-shirt size</summary>

- `s-XS`: (< 1 day) Very simple tasks that require minimal time and effort.
- `s-S`: (few days) Tasks that are straightforward but require a bit more time to complete.
- `s-M`: (1-2 weeks) Tasks that involve a moderate level of complexity and collaboration.
- `s-L`: (several weeks) Complex tasks that require significant time investment and coordination across multiple teams. 
- `s-XL`: (> 1 month) Very large and complex projects that involve extensive planning, execution, and testing. 
</details>

<details>

<summary>Content evaluation</summary>
- `a-delete`: don't need this page 
- `a-duplicate`: some content lives elsewhere 
- `a-minor`: needs small revisions 
- `a-moderate`: needs moderate revisions 
- `a-critical`: needs a lot of work
</details>

## MDX Metadata format

> We will be adding better metadata to the header of each page. 
> If I was actively searching for this page on google and this description was the search result, would I know it's the correct page?
> Parse the component and feature tags to add.

```mdx
---
title: "Your Title Here"
tags: ["tag1", "tag2"]
description: "A short description of the content."
---
```

<details>
<summary>Component tags</summary>

```
op-node
op-geth
op-reth
op-erigon
op-nethermind
batcher
standard-bridge
sequencer
l1-contracts
l2-contracts
precompiles
predeploys
preinstalls
op-proposer
op-challenger
op-gov-token
op-supervisor
op-conductor
fp-contracts
cannon
op-program
asterisk
kona
superchain-registry
supersim
dev-console
opsm
mcp
mcp-l2
deputy-guardian
liveness-guard
dispute-mon
op-beat
op-signer
monitorism
blockspace-charters
op-workbench
kubernetes-infrastructure
devops-tooling
artifacts-packaging
sequencer-in-a-box
devnets
performance-tooling
peer-management-service
proxyd
zdd-service
snapman
security-tools
superchain-ops
op-deployer
```
</details>

<details>
<summary>Engineering tags</summary>

```
eng-platforms
eng-growth
eng-devx
eng-protocol
eng-proofs
eng-evm
eng-security
```
</details>

topPRs.title: Add Support for Nethermind on OP Docs
topPRs.author: stdevMac
topPRs.body:
**Description**
We are adding support for Nethermind client on the OP Docs. 

**Tests**
We didn't add any other test since most of the changes are Documentation

**Additional context**
We have modified some sections to allow in the future to add other clients.

We are welcome to any recommendation!

topContributors.summary: devin-ai-integration: Focused on improving test quality and coverage within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository through a series of refactors. They merged three pull requests to enhance tests for `ReinitializableBase` (#17839), `SafeSend` (#17896), and `ResourceMetering` (#17812). This effort is ongoing with six additional open PRs targeting similar test improvements, and they also contributed through 18 PR comments and 2 reviews.

geoknee: This month, geoknee focused on core protocol upgrades and specifications, particularly for the upcoming Fusaka and Jovian hard forks. They delivered several impactful changes, including implementing the Jovian operator fee fix in `op-geth#696`, enabling blob proof verification in `optimism#17713` (+150/-60 lines), and clarifying defensive specifications in `specs#790`. In addition to merging six pull requests, they demonstrated proactive ownership by opening 11 issues to track necessary tests and design improvements, and supported the team by conducting 30 code reviews. Their work shows a primary focus on implementation, bug fixes, and ensuring correctness through extensive testing.

sebastianst: This month, sebastianst focused on changes related to the Jovian upgrade and data availability (DA) footprint limits across the `ethereum-optimism` ecosystem. They merged a critical fix for OP Legacy header verification (`op-geth#697`) and updated the DA footprint limit specifications to use `blobGasUsed` (`specs#800`). In addition to their merged work, they created several issues to define upcoming work for the Jovian upgrade and were highly collaborative, providing 39 code reviews. Their contributions were primarily focused on bug fixes and other feature work, touching both code and test files.

bitwiseguy: Focused on enhancing the deployment and upgrade tooling for Optimism, merging six pull requests centered on the `op-deployer`. They delivered key improvements by enabling support for v4.1.0 upgrades (optimism#17824, superchain-registry#1109) and reducing deployment costs by lowering the gas pad factor (optimism#17710). A significant effort was dedicated to improving reliability by adding extensive CLI tests in a large PR (optimism#17849, +1381/-120 lines). Alongside this implementation work, they were an active collaborator, providing 18 code reviews across the project.

maurelian: This month, maurelian focused on improving test infrastructure and contract security. They merged a refactor to make test initialization contracts abstract (optimism#17889) and have several open PRs aimed at enhancing security for SaferSafes by enforcing owner-only actions (optimism#17900, #17883). In addition to their direct contributions, they were highly engaged in collaboration, providing 36 code reviews for the team. Their work across 63 commits primarily involved modifications to test files, with a focus on bug fixes and general improvements.

smartcontracts: This month, smartcontracts focused on improving test infrastructure and supporting Superchain operations. They landed a significant fix in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#17813` to refactor tests, a complex change involving over 14,000 lines of code. Additionally, they contributed to operational readiness by adding validation instructions (`superchain-ops#1251`), tracking the Isthmus Upgrade (`optimism#12703`), and providing 11 code reviews. Their work shows a primary focus on bug fixes and features, with contributions spanning documentation, code, and test files.

Wazabie: This month, Wazabie's activity consisted of opening a pull request in the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository (#1252). This change proposes an update to a test file, modifying it by +11/-8 lines. Based on this contribution, their work was focused on tests.

ajsutton: This month, ajsutton focused on improving the reliability of the dispute monitoring system, merging a key fix in ethereum-optimism/optimism (#17831) to correctly identify invalid nodes that have not processed recent blocks. They were also a significant contributor to code quality, providing 16 reviews, and proactively identified further enhancements by opening three related issues. Their work primarily involved bug fixes and tests, demonstrating a commitment to system stability and correctness.

Inphi: This month, Inphi focused on improving the testing infrastructure and maintenance of the Optimism project. They made a key contribution by merging an integration test for the `op-deployer` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17865), which added significant test coverage. In addition to opening a new PR to update an upgrade method, they were highly collaborative, providing 18 code reviews for their peers. Their overall efforts were distributed across bug fixes, adding tests, and other general maintenance work.

scharissis: Focused on enhancing the stability and functionality of the acceptance testing framework, merging 12 PRs across the `infra` and `optimism` repositories. They delivered impactful features to the `op-acceptor`, including stricter gate exclusions (`infra#490`) and environment variable passthrough (`infra#483`), while also resolving multiple flaky tests (`optimism#17830`, `optimism#17706`). This work, supported by 9 code reviews, shows a clear focus on improving test infrastructure through a combination of feature implementation, bug fixes, and CI enhancements.

AmadiMichael: Focused on significant refactoring and enhancing the testing framework within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository this month. They landed several impactful pull requests, including adding end-to-end upgrade tests (#17826) and removing a substantial amount of unused code related to the superchain proxy admin (#17828). In addition to their direct contributions, they were an active collaborator, providing 19 code reviews for teammates. Their work primarily involved modifications to tests and configuration files, reflecting a focus on bug fixes and overall system stability.

pcw109550 focused on enhancing the reliability of the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository by expanding acceptance test coverage for core syncing logic. They made a significant contribution by adding extensive new tests for reorg and gap-filling scenarios in PR #17893 (+521 lines). Additionally, pcw109550 improved the testing framework by caching L2EL payloads (#17675) and fixed bugs related to payload queue syncing (#17712) and fork choice updates (#17894). Their work was primarily concentrated on tests and other related code changes.

mds1: Focused on supporting team velocity this month through extensive code review. They provided valuable feedback across numerous changes, completing 38 reviews which included 15 approvals. No pull requests were merged during this period.

alcueca: Contributed to the team's progress this month primarily through code review. They reviewed 3 pull requests, providing 2 approvals and leaving comments to help advance ongoing work. Their code contributions consisted of 3 commits focused on bug fixes and other work.

pauldowman focused on enhancing the dispute and challenge mechanisms within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. His most impactful contribution was the addition of a `skip-blob-verification` flag, a significant feature delivered in a complex PR (#17718) that modified over 550 lines of code. He also improved the dispute monitor's error handling (#17819) and actively supported the team by providing 10 code reviews. His work shows a clear focus on core application logic and its corresponding test coverage.

mbaxter: Focused on significant feature development this month, contributing a substantial volume of code changes (+1843/-839 lines) primarily across configuration files. This work appears related to the v2 dispute game implementation, a feature they proposed in issue #17257. In addition to this primary effort, mbaxter improved CI by enabling an isolated devfeature test (PR #17702) and actively supported the team by providing 13 code reviews.

sbvegan: Undertook a significant refactoring effort this month, modifying 457 files with over 15k lines added and 31k lines deleted across 4 commits. This work was evenly split between bugfixes and other tasks. In addition to this coding effort, they supported the team by reviewing and approving 3 pull requests.

joshklop: Focused on improving the robustness and configuration of the Optimism node and client services, authoring significant changes across 101 files (+3398/-896 lines). This work is captured in several open pull requests aimed at improving beacon client robustness (#17866), node configuration (#17691), and test environment alignment (#17881). In addition to this feature work, they merged a small fix for the devstack (#17904) and initiated architectural discussions by opening new issues (#342, #17703). Their code contributions were primarily focused on general development, testing, and bug fixes.

nonsense: Focused on improving node reliability through testing and core logic updates. They merged an acceptance test in ethereum-optimism/optimism#17696 to verify chain stall conditions, enhancing the test suite's coverage. In addition to providing 8 code reviews, they also began work on updating payload handling in the op-node via the open PR ethereum-optimism/optimism#17751. Their work this month was split between improving tests and modifying core node code.

opgitgovernance: Focused on improving test reliability within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository through a significant refactoring effort. They merged a large pull request (#17851) aimed at reducing test flakiness, which involved a substantial cleanup of over 6,500 lines of code. This work is ongoing with three additional open pull requests in the same area, and they actively participated in discussions with 17 PR comments, demonstrating a clear focus on improving test infrastructure.

aliersh: Focused on enhancing the testing infrastructure within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository this month. They implemented significant new features, including adding library support for test validation (#17690) and introducing Slack notifications to the AI contracts test suite (#17876). In addition to this feature work, aliersh also resolved several test-related bugs to improve reliability (#17840, #17709). This work demonstrates a clear focus on improving test functionality and stability, with code changes almost exclusively affecting test files.

MSilb7: This month, MSilb7's work was focused within the `ethereum-optimism/op-analytics` repository, where they merged two pull requests. Their most significant contribution involved modifying revenue wallets in PR #1754, which included over 800 lines of additions. They also shipped fixes to collective balances in PR #1755, with their overall activity split between bug fixes and other work, and a quarter of all file changes affecting configuration.

janjakubnanista: This month, janjakubnanista focused on improving CI and operational stability, primarily through on-call responsibilities. They proactively identified and created several issues to track system health, including failing CI RPC calls (#17754, #17688) and a need for log retention (#17859). In addition, they merged a pull request to improve CI error messages in the superchain-registry (#1118) and supported the team by providing 4 code reviews. Their work primarily involved bug fixes and other improvements through modifications to configuration files.

axelKingsley: Focused on the `op-supernode` component this month, merging a key pull request to set its v0.1.0 version and Docker image target (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17906). They actively engaged with the team's work by providing 13 review comments and opened a new issue to improve the `op-conductor` component (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17879). While merged changes were small, a significant volume of code was committed (+8831/-1632 lines), indicating substantial work in progress primarily focused on new development, testing, and bug fixes.

jelias2: This month, jelias2 focused on the `ethereum-optimism/infra` repository, merging a fix for a typo in `conductor-ops` (infra#492). They also have ongoing work to test CircleCI modifications in an open pull request (infra#484). In addition to these contributions, jelias2 actively supported the team by providing five approving reviews on other pull requests. Their work primarily involved feature updates to both code and configuration files.

JosepBove: This month, JosepBove focused on operational improvements, merging a refactor of base commands in `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops#1241` (+99/-46 lines). They also proposed a new feature to add `IERC165` support in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#17864` and actively supported the team's work by providing 7 code reviews. Their contributions were primarily centered on bugfixes, with code changes concentrated in test, configuration, and documentation files.

bradleycamacho: Focused on a significant information architecture restructure within the `ethereum-optimism/docs` repository. They opened two substantial pull requests (#1791, #1792) proposing a major overhaul of the documentation, which involved modifying 282 files with over 9,200 additions and 8,400 deletions. Alongside this primary effort, they also contributed 3 code reviews to support the team.
almanax-ai: No activity this month.

mslipper: Focused on planning and scoping key initiatives within the Optimism ecosystem this month. They created several issues to track significant workstreams, including the implementation of the "Scalar Fix" specification (#17002), the first milestone for the "OP Supernode" (#17558), and an investigation into a Celestia batcher fix (#17872). This activity demonstrates a focus on protocol-level specifications and integrations.
